abstract.text: This view mimics native iOS system keyboards, like standard
alphabetic, numeric and symbolic system keyboards.

inlineContent.text: There are several ways to create a system keyboard:
One is to use the builder-less initializer to create a view
that uses standard buttons.
Another is to use the
initializer to create
a view that customizes the intrinsic content of each button,
but doesn’t affect its shape.
A third is to use the
initializer, to create a
view that customizes the entire view for each button.
You also have
-based initializers that are more
convenient to use than the initializers that require you to
inject a layout, appearance, services, contexts etc.
Since the keyboard button widths depends on the total width,
you must provide the view with a
. If you do not, it
will use the
which uses the width
of the shared input view controller view.
If you look at the initializer source code, you may find it
strange that the default values for
and
are nil instead of the values, and that the values are then
resolved within the initializer. The reason is that there’s
a bug in Xcode, that makes the default init parameters fail
to compile when they’re part of a binary framework. As such,
we make the default parameter values
and then resolve
the values in the initializer body instead, which fixes the
bonary framework problem.
On iOS 14, the keyboard will automatically switch to use an
if
changes to

abstract.text: This view mimics the buttons that are used in an iOS system
keyboard. It wraps a
view and uses a
to resolves its content.
This view renders a standard title for an emoji category.
This view represents the bottom shadow of a standard system
keyboard button. Instead of being added as a shadow, it has
to be added as an overlay, and will cut out the shadow that
will be placed below the button shape.
This menu can be used to list a set of emoji categories and
let each category button toggle a category selection.
Create a system keyboard view that uses standard button
views for all layout items.
KeyboardKit helps you build custom keyboards with Swift and SwiftUI.
The standard view to use as button content.
This view is the part of the callout that covers the button
that was tapped or pressed to trigger the callout.
This view mimics text in a system keyboard button.
This view can be used to list an emoji collection using the
provided configuration.
This view mimics the content of a system space button, that
starts with displaying the provided
then fades
to the
(or
This protocol can be used to create text inputs that should
be used within a keyboard extension, and therefore must set
themselves as the current text document proxy while they’re
being edited.
This view mimics the buttons that are used in an iOS system
keyboard. It wraps the provided content and applies a style.
This view renders a standard button for an emoji.
This view is meant to be used within a
and
will apply the frames and paddings to the view, to mitigate
dead tap areas, as well the correct appearance, style, view
gestures etc.
A
can be used to list actions in a grid with
a certain number of
Create a system keyboard view that uses
to customize the content of each layout item.
This view replicates the standard autocomplete toolbar item
title text that is used in native iOS keyboards.
This view replicates the standard autocomplete toolbar item
subtitle text that is used in native iOS keyboards.
This keyboard lists all emojis from a selected category, as
well as a menu that lets the user select a new category and
change back to an alphabetic keyboard.
This is the standard keyboard width, which is retrieved
from
This callout can be used to show the currently typed action
above the pressed keyboard button.
The keyboard type that is currently used.
The shared input view controller. This is registered as
the keyboard extension is started.
This view represents the body of a standard system keyboard
button, excluding the button text or image.
This view replicates the standard autocomplete toolbar item
that is used in native iOS keyboards.
This view mimics a system keyboard space button with custom
content that takes up as much horizontal space as needed.
This callout can be used to present alternate actions for a
keyboard certain keyboard action.
The standard view to use as button view.
Create a system keyboard view that uses
to customize the content of each layout item.
represents keyboards that either present emoji
characters or emoji categories.
This button switches to the next keyboard when it is tapped
and opens a keyboard switcher menu when it is pressed.
This view can be used when you want to have multi-line text
input in a keyboard extension, and the input should receive
the text that is typed on the keyboard.
This view can be used when you want to have a text field in
a keyboard extension, and the text field should receive the
text that is typed on the keyboard.
This view replicates the standard autocomplete toolbar item
separator that is used in native iOS keyboards.
This typealias specifies the standard button content that a
will use by default.
This view mimics native iOS system keyboards, like standard
alphabetic, numeric and symbolic system keyboards.
This button shows an image with a tap and long press action.
This curve can be used to smoothen the part where a callout
bubble meets the button area.
Create a system keyboard that uses a custom
to customize the entire view for each layout item.
This view is a horizontal row with autocomplete buttons and
separator lines between the buttons.
This view resolves the correct content for a certain action,
which will result in either a text or image, or nothing. It
also sets up line limits, vertical offsets etc.
This typealias specifies the standard button view, that the
will use by default.
Create a system keyboard view that uses standard button
views for all layout items.
